CD 1 Tom Masculino:
Among the many male voices singing Jobim Caetano Veloso has been something of a devot, with Jobim pieces finding their way frequently into his concert and records.
The breatthtaking version of Eu sei que vou te amar featured here, comes from his 1978 album, Muito.
Several key bossa nova artists showcse Jobim's work of the period, from Lucio Alves proto-bossa rendition of the sensous Dindi to classic peformance like Tamba Trio's Agua de beber, Sergio Mnendes and Bossa Rio's Corcovado and bossa pioneer Joao Donato's So danÃ§o samba.

CD2 Tom Feminino:
Brasil has a surplus of amazing female voices, and Jobim's intricate pieces fit most of them perfectly. 
From Gal Costa's pure soprano-Desafinado, a true bossa nova anthem-to Maria Bethania's eartly contralto-the sweet Modinha-from Leny Andrade's swinging groove-Samba do aviao, recorded live-to Nara Leao's intimate rendition of Chega de saudade,
Jobim music acquired new rich tones. Elis Regina-with whom jobim recorded an anthological duet album in 1972-shines through withthe lyrical Estradas do sol.

CD3 Tom Pra Dois:
Shell we dance? A classic bossa nova pair, lucio Alves and Sylva Telles, show how its done in Este seu olhar/So em teu braÃ§os; real life (at this moment) couple, Astrud and Joao Gilberto, give us international version in their major hit, Garota de Ipanema.
Just to keep things in the family, Jobim's grandson Daniel takles Samba de Maria Luiz with the song's muse Maria Luiza, his aunt.
But larger parties can do it to- and to perfection: two master vocal ensemble, MPB4 and quarteto em CY, join forced in a delightul sequence of some of Jobim's famous songs.
